content.text: The functional physical area repository contains a collection of functional physical areas used to describe the components and systems of a bicycle. The repository is organized into a hierarchical structure, with each level representing a more specific or detailed description of the component or system.

category.name: Top-Level Categories
category.item: Steering: Components related to steering the bicycle.
Drivetrain: Components related to transmitting power from the pedals to the wheels.
Gears: Components related to changing the gear ratio of the drivetrain.
Brakes: Components related to slowing or stopping the bicycle.

category.name: Steering Sub-Categories
category.item: Handlebars: The component that connects the rider's hands to the front wheel.
Stem: The component that connects the handlebars to the frame.
Fork: The component that connects the front wheel to the frame.

category.name: Drivetrain Sub-Categories
category.item: Chainrings: The components that transmit power from the pedals to the chain.
Chain: The component that transmits power from the chainrings to the cassette.
Cassette: The component that contains the gears that the chain engages with.

category.name: Gears Sub-Categories
category.item: Derailleurs: The components that move the chain between different gears on the cassette.
Shifters: The components that control the derailleurs to change the gear ratio.
Cassette: The component that contains the gears that the chain engages with.

category.name: Brakes Sub-Categories
category.item: Brake Calipers: The components that apply pressure to the brake pads to slow or stop the wheel.
Brake Pads: The components that contact the rim or rotor to slow or stop the wheel.
Levers: The components that control the brake calipers to apply pressure to the brake pads.

exampleUseCases.useCase: A bicycle manufacturer uses the functional physical area repository to describe the components and systems of their latest model.
A cyclist uses the repository to identify the specific component that needs to be replaced or upgraded on their bike.
A mechanic uses the repository to understand the relationships between different components and systems when performing repairs or maintenance.
